articles.title: All aboard the clean power express: Colorado startup turns trains into rolling batteries
articles.summary:
BY THE OPTIMIST DAILY EDITORIAL TEAM For over a century, America’s railroads hauled coal by the ton, fueling the country’s insatiable appetite for fossil energy. Now, a Colorado startup is flipping that script by replacing coal with clean power. Meet SunTrain, the Denver-based company that’s converting freight railcars into rolling batteries capable of transporting renewable […]
The post All aboard the clean power express: Colorado startup turns trains into rolling batteries first appeared on The Optimist Daily: Making Solutions the News.
articles.content:
BY THE OPTIMIST DAILY EDITORIAL TEAM

For over a century, America’s railroads hauled coal by the ton, fueling the country’s insatiable appetite for fossil energy. Now, a Colorado startup is flipping that script by replacing coal with clean power. Meet SunTrain, the Denver-based company that’s converting freight railcars into rolling batteries capable of transporting renewable energy across the country.

How it works: trains as mega-batteries

Instead of shuttling lumps of coal, these railcars are crammed with high-capacity batteries. Each one stores 17.2 megawatt-hours of electricity. That’s enough to power about 12,000 homes for an hour. Link multiple cars together, and suddenly you’ve got hundreds of megawatt-hours chugging along America’s 140,000 miles of freight track.

SunTrain proved the concept wasn’t just theoretical. Its prototype railcar logged over 10,000 miles on Union Pacific tracks across California and Colorado, dropping off stored electricity to power grids along the way. Think of it as Amtrak for electrons.

Why we need it

Here’s the catch with renewable energy: solar panels and wind turbines tend to make power when it’s sunny or windy, not necessarily when people flip on the lights. Battery storage solves that mismatch, but there’s another snag. How can clean power be transported from remote renewable farms to the cities that need it? Building new high-voltage transmission lines is a permitting and legal nightmare, often dragging on for two decades. SunTrain skips that hassle entirely by using the railroads we already have.

The idea is refreshingly simple. There are no new land grabs, no environmental studies, no multi-year permitting battles. We simply need to roll the batteries down the tracks.

The pilot project: Pueblo to Denver

SunTrain isn’t just daydreaming. In fact, it’s already gearing up for a pilot project with Xcel Energy in Colorado. A 20-car train will haul 344 megawatt-hours of wind and solar power from farms near Pueblo straight into a former coal power plant in downtown Denver. The symbolism couldn’t be sharper: a coal plant reborn as a clean energy hub.

The company has raised $2.25 million in funding, plus another $3 million in venture capital, and is now eyeing a $12–15 million round to bring the pilot to life. If successful, it could show utilities how to retire dirty natural gas peaker plants in favor of mobile clean energy delivery.

Big picture potential

The U.S. energy grid is creaking under the weight of outdated transmission lines and political roadblocks. SunTrain offers a desirable shortcut. The founders, who have already developed more than $2 billion worth of electrical infrastructure projects, estimate a pipeline of 32 gigawatt-hours of potential railroad energy projects.

Former coal plants are especially ripe for this transition. They already have the grid hookups needed to handle large-scale power injections. Instead of tearing them down, SunTrain envisions turning them into clean energy gateways.

Why it matters

Mobile energy storage trains won’t solve every grid problem, but they could prove invaluable in bridging the geographic gap between where renewable energy is produced and where it’s actually needed. They also cut out the most contentious part of energy expansion: building new transmission lines.

The concept is simple yet elegant: take something America already has (a vast rail network), give it a clean tech makeover, and turn yesterday’s coal convoys into tomorrow’s clean energy trains. All aboard.

articles.title: Mammoth challenge: why we called our de-extinction company Colossal Biosciences
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 25 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02668-7Chief executive Ben Lamm says the name aims to capture biodiversity challenges and excite children about a flagship species.
articles.content:
Colossal Biosciences as a company name was picked to engage children, says chief executive Ben Lamm.Credit: Colossal Biosciences

The meaning behind our moniker Colossal Biosciences, in Dallas, Texas, describes itself as the world’s first de-extinction company. It aims to revive lost species using CRISPR gene-editing technology, including the mammoth (Mammuthus spp.). It attracted controversy when it announced it has ‘de-extincted’ the dire wolf (Aenocyon dirus), a large-bodied wolf species that last roamed North America during the ice age that ended some 11,500 years ago. Its co-founders are technology entrepreneur Ben Lamm, Colossal’s chief executive, and George Church, the company’s genetics adviser, who also holds academic research positions at Harvard Medical School and Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge. In the third article of a six-part series about science-company names and how to choose them, Lamm describes how the name ‘Colossal Biosciences’ came about.

The fact that the world will lose up to 25% of all biodiversity between now and 2050 is a huge problem. At my company, we asked ourselves, how do we come up with a name that encompasses three elements: the problem, the solution and our flagship species, the mammoth?

Climate change, biodiversity, CRISPR and gene editing, artificial intelligence, computational analysis and advanced embryology can be difficult concepts for the public to fully grasp. We came up with ‘Colossal Biosciences’ because losing species is a colossal problem, our solution is colossal and the mammoth is a colossal animal.

We felt that our brand and name should not only reflect the problem and solution, but also be approachable to children, including some who will grow up to read Cell, Nature and Science. Every week, we get little pictures of dodos and baby mammoths that kids draw, and their parents mail us physical letters, saying things such as: ‘Thank you so much for doing what you’re doing. My kid is excited about science. You’re making science cool.’

A big, awesome name

To come up with Colossal, I worked with Chris Klee, executive vice-president of design at the company, and Chris Stevens, co-founder of Maven Creative, our branding agency, in Orlando, Florida.

We’ve worked together for the past 20 years. We had a list of seven or eight potential names — including ‘Huge’, ‘Macedon’ (an ancient kingdom) and ‘Footprint’ (because every species has a unique one). Everything was centred around the concept of ‘big and awesome’. Obviously, ‘Mammoth’ was on the list because the world is facing a mammoth challenge, but we felt that calling it that would have pigeonholed us to one species.

We also liked ‘Colossus’, and the idea of using ‘us’ to signify a team effort. But Colossus is a character in the Marvel Universe media franchise, and we didn’t want to be too Hollywood. We also considered names linked to evolution, and thought ‘Darwin’ could be a cool one. But when we said ‘Colossal’ out loud, we were like, ‘That’s it!’

Alongside the name, there’s the brand — so before we decided on Colossal, we underwent a process to come up with a brand that encapsulated ‘Harvard University meets 1980’s MTV’.

articles.personality_title: Green industrial policies reshape global efforts to cut carbon emissions
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – For years, countries have been working to reduce carbon emissions and fight climate change. Recently, a new approach called green industrial policy has started changing how governments support clean energy and decarbonization, which means cutting down the amount of harmful gases released into the air.

**What happened** – Researchers have observed that green industrial policies are now playing a big role in shaping the energy transition worldwide. These policies involve governments actively supporting renewable energy industries, like solar and wind power, through investments, rules, and trade measures. This shift is happening across many countries, including the US, China, and those in Europe, changing how clean energy technologies spread and compete globally.

**Impact** – This change is important because it moves decarbonization from just being about cutting emissions to also being about economic growth and national strategies. Countries are not only trying to protect the environment but also to create new jobs and industries in clean energy. This approach affects international trade and cooperation, causing both opportunities for partnerships and challenges like trade conflicts. It highlights how climate action is closely linked with economic and political decisions.

**What's next step** – Experts say more research is needed to understand how these green policies work best and how countries can cooperate to avoid conflicts while speeding up clean energy use. Policymakers will likely focus on designing smart policies that balance environmental goals with economic needs and international relations.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Green industrial policies are changing how the world fights climate change by linking environmental goals with economic strategies and global cooperation.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les politiques industrielles vertes transforment les efforts mondiaux pour réduire les émissions de carbone
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Depuis des années, les pays cherchent à réduire leurs émissions de carbone pour lutter contre le changement climatique. Récemment, une nouvelle approche appelée politique industrielle verte a commencé à changer la manière dont les gouvernements soutiennent les énergies propres et la décarbonation, c’est-à-dire la réduction des gaz nocifs dans l’atmosphère.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs ont observé que les politiques industrielles vertes jouent désormais un rôle essentiel dans la transition énergétique mondiale. Ces politiques impliquent un soutien actif des gouvernements aux industries des énergies renouvelables, comme le solaire et l’éolien, grâce à des investissements, des règles et des mesures commerciales. Ce changement se produit dans plusieurs pays, notamment aux États-Unis, en Chine et en Europe, modifiant la diffusion et la compétition des technologies propres à l’échelle mondiale.

**Impact** – Ce changement est important car il transforme la décarbonation en un enjeu à la fois environnemental et économique. Les pays cherchent non seulement à protéger la planète, mais aussi à créer des emplois et des industries dans les énergies propres. Cette approche influence le commerce international et la coopération, offrant des opportunités de partenariat mais aussi des défis comme des conflits commerciaux. Elle montre que l’action climatique est liée aux décisions économiques et politiques.

**Prochaine étape** – Les experts recommandent davantage de recherches pour mieux comprendre le fonctionnement de ces politiques vertes et comment les pays peuvent coopérer pour éviter les conflits et accélérer l’usage des énergies propres. Les décideurs vont probablement chercher à concevoir des politiques intelligentes qui équilibrent objectifs environnementaux, besoins économiques et relations internationales.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les politiques industrielles vertes changent la lutte mondiale contre le changement climatique en associant objectifs environnementaux, stratégies économiques et coopération internationale.
articles.personality_title_es: Las políticas industriales verdes transforman los esfuerzos globales para reducir las emisiones de carbono
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Durante años, los países han trabajado para reducir las emisiones de carbono y combatir el cambio climático. Recientemente, un nuevo enfoque llamado política industrial verde ha comenzado a cambiar cómo los gobiernos apoyan las energías limpias y la descarbonización, que significa reducir los gases dañinos en el aire.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores han observado que las políticas industriales verdes ahora juegan un papel importante en la transición energética mundial. Estas políticas implican que los gobiernos apoyan activamente las industrias de energías renovables, como la solar y la eólica, mediante inversiones, normas y medidas comerciales. Este cambio ocurre en muchos países, incluidos Estados Unidos, China y Europa, cambiando cómo las tecnologías limpias se difunden y compiten globalmente.

**Impacto** – Este cambio es importante porque transforma la descarbonización de solo reducir emisiones a incluir crecimiento económico y estrategias nacionales. Los países no solo intentan proteger el medio ambiente, sino también crear empleos e industrias en energía limpia. Este enfoque afecta el comercio y la cooperación internacional, creando oportunidades de asociación y desafíos como conflictos comerciales. Muestra que la acción climática está muy ligada a decisiones económicas y políticas.

**Próximo paso** – Los expertos dicen que se necesita más investigación para entender mejor cómo funcionan estas políticas verdes y cómo los países pueden cooperar para evitar conflictos y acelerar el uso de energía limpia. Los responsables de políticas probablemente se enfocarán en diseñar políticas inteligentes que equilibren objetivos ambientales, necesidades económicas y relaciones internacionales.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Las políticas industriales verdes están cambiando la forma en que el mundo combate el cambio climático al unir metas ambientales con estrategias económicas y cooperación global.

articles.title: This flower smells like dying ants, and flies can’t resist it
articles.summary: Vincetoxicum nakaianum tricks flies into pollinating it by imitating the smell of ants attacked by spiders. Ko Mochizuki stumbled upon this finding when he noticed flies clustering around the flowers and later confirmed their unusual preference. The study reveals the first known case of ant odor mimicry in plants, expanding our understanding of how diverse floral deception can be.
articles.content:
Ko Mochizuki of the University of Tokyo has discovered that Vincetoxicum nakaianum, a dogbane species native to Japan described for the first time by Mochizuki and his collaborators only a year ago, mimics the smell of ants attacked by spiders to attract flies that feed on such attacked insects, and in the process pollinate the flowers. This is the first case of a plant mimicking the odor of ants, revealing that the scope of floral mimicry is more diverse than previously imagined. The findings are published in the journal Current Biology.

The smell of warm, freshly baked bread has surely attracted many a customer to enter the shop as they pass by. Grass flies are no different: they are also attracted to the smell of their daily bread, injured ants. As they move from flower to flower in search of already injured prey, they also do flowers a great service: they pollinate them. Because ants are one of the most widespread species, and ant mimicry has independently evolved in many invertebrate species, it stands to reason that plants could have also evolved to mimic ants in one way or another. However, such cases had never been reported.

"I was working on another research project," says Ko Mochizuki, "and originally collected this species only as a 'reference' for comparison. By chance, I noticed chloropid flies gathering around its flowers in the nursery in the Koishikawa Botanical Gardens, and immediately realized that the flowers might be imitating dead insects."

This recognition was thanks to a string of thus far unrelated experiences. His participation in an intensive training course in 2019 helped him recognize the fly species swarming the flower. He also happened to be familiar with some previous studies that described plants pollinated by chloropid flies emitting odors resembling those of insects.

Following his hunch, Mochizuki set out to methodically observe the visitors on these flowers and compare the odors released by the flowers to odors released by various kinds of insects. He found that the smell of ants being attacked by spiders was the closest match. However, his hypothesis of ant mimicry was standing on frail legs: there had not been any official publications of chloropid flies, or any other similar fly species, targeting ants hunted and injured by other animals, such as spiders. So, Mochizuki turned to social media for more unconventional evidence. There, he found many amateur naturalists documenting what he had suspected: ants attacked by spiders, which then attracted kleptoparasitic (organisms that steal food from another) flies. This gave him confidence to test the hypothesis behaviorally and confirm whether chloropid flies were indeed more attracted to the smell of ants attacked by spiders than to other smells.

"That moment, when I saw the flies on the flowers, was truly one of inspiration," Mochizuki remembers, "a hypothesis suddenly taking shape. This experience taught me that unexpected discoveries often emerge from a combination of preparation and chance."

Talking of preparation… Mochizuki is already preparing for the next project.

"I would like to investigate the evolutionary background of ant mimicry by comparing the pollination systems, evolutionary history, and genetic makeup of Vincetoxicum nakaianum and its close relatives. In addition, since this study suggests that many forms of floral mimicry may remain hidden, I plan to explore other species, both within Vincetoxicum and in unrelated plant groups, to uncover further examples of potential mimicry."

This discovery broadens understanding of biodiversity and ecological relationships, which has meaningful implications for environmental science and conservation. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights a significant breakthrough in plant biology with broad ecological relevance.
articles.personality_title: Japanese flower tricks flies by smelling like injured ants
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have long known that plants use smells to attract insects for pollination, but no plant had been shown to copy the smell of ants before. Ants are common insects, and some animals mimic them for protection or hunting.

**What happened** – Ko Mochizuki, a researcher at the University of Tokyo, discovered that a Japanese flower called Vincetoxicum nakaianum uses a smell similar to ants attacked by spiders. This smell attracts grass flies, which usually look for injured ants to eat. When the flies visit the flower, they help pollinate it. Mochizuki noticed this by chance when he saw many flies around the flowers and then tested the smells carefully.

**Impact** – This is the first time scientists have found a plant copying the smell of ants, showing that plants can use more complex tricks than we thought to get pollinated. It helps us better understand how plants and insects interact and how nature uses clever methods to survive and reproduce.

**What's next step** – Mochizuki plans to study how this ant smell trick evolved by comparing this flower to close relatives. He also wants to look for other plants that might use similar or different tricks to attract insects.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A Japanese flower uses the smell of injured ants to attract flies that pollinate it, revealing a new type of plant deception.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une fleur japonaise attire les mouches en imitant l’odeur des fourmis blessées
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques savent que les plantes utilisent des odeurs pour attirer les insectes et être pollinisées, mais aucune plante n’avait encore été montrée comme imitant l’odeur des fourmis. Les fourmis sont des insectes très communs, et certains animaux les imitent pour se protéger ou chasser.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Ko Mochizuki, chercheur à l’Université de Tokyo, a découvert qu’une fleur japonaise appelée Vincetoxicum nakaianum dégage une odeur semblable à celle des fourmis attaquées par des araignées. Cette odeur attire des mouches des herbes, qui cherchent normalement des fourmis blessées pour se nourrir. En visitant la fleur, ces mouches la pollinisent. Mochizuki a remarqué cela par hasard en voyant beaucoup de mouches autour des fleurs, puis a testé les odeurs.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois qu’on trouve une plante qui copie l’odeur des fourmis, montrant que les plantes utilisent des astuces plus complexes qu’on ne le pensait pour se faire polliniser. Cela aide à mieux comprendre comment plantes et insectes interagissent et comment la nature utilise des méthodes ingénieuses pour survivre.

**Prochaines étapes** – Mochizuki veut étudier comment cette astuce d’odeur de fourmi a évolué en comparant cette fleur à ses proches parentes. Il souhaite aussi chercher d’autres plantes qui pourraient utiliser des astuces similaires ou différentes pour attirer les insectes.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Une fleur japonaise utilise l’odeur de fourmis blessées pour attirer des mouches qui la pollinisent, révélant un nouveau type de tromperie chez les plantes.
articles.personality_title_es: Una flor japonesa atrae moscas imitando el olor de hormigas heridas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos saben que las plantas usan olores para atraer insectos y ser polinizadas, pero nunca se había visto que una planta imitara el olor de las hormigas. Las hormigas son insectos muy comunes, y algunos animales las imitan para protegerse o cazar.

**Qué pasó** – Ko Mochizuki, investigador de la Universidad de Tokio, descubrió que una flor japonesa llamada Vincetoxicum nakaianum tiene un olor parecido al de hormigas atacadas por arañas. Este olor atrae moscas de hierba, que normalmente buscan hormigas heridas para alimentarse. Cuando las moscas visitan la flor, la polinizan. Mochizuki notó esto por casualidad al ver muchas moscas en las flores y luego comparó los olores.

**Impacto** – Es la primera vez que se encuentra una planta que imita el olor de las hormigas, mostrando que las plantas usan trucos más complejos de lo que se pensaba para atraer insectos. Esto ayuda a entender mejor cómo interactúan las plantas y los insectos, y cómo la naturaleza usa métodos ingeniosos para sobrevivir.

**Próximos pasos** – Mochizuki planea estudiar cómo evolucionó este truco del olor a hormiga comparando esta flor con sus parientes cercanos. También quiere buscar otras plantas que puedan usar trucos similares o diferentes para atraer insectos.

**Resumen en una frase** – Una flor japonesa usa el olor de hormigas heridas para atraer moscas que la polinizan, revelando un nuevo tipo de engaño en plantas.
